I am new here, but I think this question deserves a much more serious and in depth examination than it has received so far.
 
 Every time I turn around someone is complaining about about something, and almost invariably, whatever the problem may be, it is sourced to the public education system. Just what is so bad about modern public education? Is it better in Europe or Asia, Latin America or Africa? Just exactly what are the criteria by which 'a good education' may be adjudicated? Just what exactly should a publicly funded system of education be expected to accomplish with a society's children over the course of 12 years intensive training, that is, what should the goals of public education be, and what goals are beyond its abilities, and what skills, abilities, and stores of knowledge are irrelevent to the goals that a truly excellent education system should be striving to attain?
 
 I'll be surprised if any two people here agree entirely about what education should be about, so how can any system be any good if nobody can agree on just what it is that it is supposed to accomplish?
 
 Hope somebody is interested in discussing this.

I would like to go deeper and seek a basic philosophy of education. What, really, is education for; that is, who does the system serve?
 
 It seems to me that since the 60's education the basic philosophy of education is that it is supposed to serve the students and their supposed needs. That is one core assumption of one philosophy of education.
 
 Authoritarian regimes with a fascist underpinning, even where nominally 'socialist', say the basic purpose of an education system is to serve the 'the state', by which they mean themselves, the ruling class, the cadres of corporate and political power brokers. 
 
 Another philosophy is the conservative approach, wherebye the parents, viewed as having 'property rights' to their own children, insist that they have the right to order the system to do exactly what they tell it to do. IOW, that curriculum, pedagogy, methods, materials, and all else be their decision, and no-one else's. Most particularly, not the responsibility of either professional educators, the state, the society as a whole, or, above all else, the children themselves.
 
 The last philosophical premise of education I can think of off the top of my head, (doubtless there are others), is that public education should not be centred upon, nor directed to the advantage of, any particular segment of society, (such as the ruling elites, the parents, the children involved, or the bureaucrats/public servants who run it, or the teachers who actually carry out the duties involved), but to the 'summum bono' of the entire society, as a single, whole, intergrated community, no matter how demographically pluralistic it may be. This is, of course, my choice in the matter.
